title: Social Security Expansion Under Consideration Would Boost Payroll Taxes
text:
WASHINGTON—House Democrats are debating whether to advance a significant expansion of Social Security that would extend the program’s solvency and increase benefits by raising taxes on top earners and middle-income workers.

The combination of tax increases, tax cuts and larger benefits would make the program solvent for at least 75 years, according to the chief actuary of the Social Security Administration. Under current law, the program’s trust funds would be exhausted by 2035 and Congress would have to add more money to keep existing benefits.

Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee met for several hours Monday night and again Tuesday to discuss the proposal from Rep. John Larson (D., Conn.). But with Republicans controlling the Senate and the White House, Mr. Larson’s measure is exceedingly unlikely to become law in this Congress.

His Social Security 2100 Act would increase benefits across the board and boost the minimum benefit. It would also lower income taxes on Social Security benefits. Under current law, individuals with income of at least $25,000 and married couples with incomes of $32,000 must pay income taxes on a portion of their benefits. The bill would raise those thresholds to $50,000 and $100,000.

The most controversial piece would be the proposed payroll-tax increases, which total more than $1 trillion over the next decade, according to the Joint Committee on Taxation. Currently, employers and employees each pay 6.2% of wages up to $132,900, and that wage cap increases each year. Mr. Larson’s bill would immediately begin imposing the tax on wages above $400,000, mirroring ideas Democrats have considered for years. But he goes further, proposing to increase the tax rate from 6.2% to 7.4% over 25 years.

Currently, someone making $50,000 faces an employee-side Social Security payroll tax of $3,100 a year. Under the bill, that tax bill would rise to $3,125 in 2020, which Mr. Larson pitches as an extra 50 cents a week. The tax would continue rising until 2043, when it would hit $3,700. Employers would face the same tax increase. Economists generally think workers bear the cost of both sides of the tax.

Mr. Larson argues for the bill as a way to counteract gender and racial wage gaps and make up for the decline of defined-benefit pensions and labor unions.

“This is going to become the newest civil-rights issue,” he said.

Many Democratic presidential candidates support expanding Social Security, but the issue hasn’t been particularly prominent in the campaign, taking a back seat to proposals to dramatically expand Medicare.

Republicans have signaled their opposition to the bill during a July hearing and again this week.

“If Democrats were truly interested in strengthening Social Security, we would be doing this on a bipartisan basis,” Rep. Kevin Brady of Texas, the top Republican on Ways and Means, said Tuesday. “The Democrats’ plan raises taxes on low-income, hardworking Americans while giving more benefits to millionaires.”

Conventional wisdom in Washington has long been that Social Security changes have to be bipartisan, because of the political risks for Democrats in raising taxes and for Republicans in cutting future benefits. But House Democrats are now thinking about moving ahead by themselves, risking political blowback.

“If your goal is not to do anything, which is their goal, then how are they ever going to work with us?” Mr. Larson said of Republicans.

Rep. Don Beyer (D., Va.) said he expected the Ways and Means panel to vote before Thanksgiving. And Mr. Larson said he thought the committee would move this month. Mr. Larson’s bill already has 210 co-sponsors from the progressive and moderate wings of the party, putting him close to having a majority of the House.

“It’s a tough one, but it’s one we’ve got to do,” said Rep. Dan Kildee (D., Mich.)

Rep. Richard Neal (D., Mass.), the Ways and Means Committee chairman, held the July hearing. He is a co-sponsor of the bill, along with enough other Ways and Means Democrats to make a majority.

But on Tuesday, Mr. Neal wouldn’t say directly whether the committee would vote. Asked whether he liked the bill as it is, Mr. Neal said: “What John Larson has done is helpful to public debate.”

Many left-leaning organizations back Mr. Larson. Still, the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a progressive group, has argued against Mr. Larson’s proposed cuts to income taxes on Social Security benefits, because it would tend to give more help to higher-income households.

Rep. Ron Kind (D., Wis.), a Ways and Means member who hasn’t co-sponsored the bill, said lawmakers need more time to discuss the issue with newer members of Congress.

“We’ve all known that the sooner you can address the reforms that are needed, the less painful it becomes,” he said. “The longer you wait, the more draconian it becomes.”

Mr. Kind said he has asked Mr. Larson to consider approaches other than a payroll-tax increase that hits lower-income workers.

“I would not be surprised if we try to move forward in committee,” he said. “But I think there’s clearly more work that needs to be done.”
